clinical_study.brief_title: Predictors and Outcomes of Intraoperative Hypothermia in Patients Undergoing Knee Arthroplasty
clinical_study.official_title: Predictors and Outcomes of Intraoperative Hypothermia in Patients Undergoing Total Knee Arthroplasty: A Retrospective Cross-sectional Study From a Developing Country

brief_summary.textblock: The study is designed to retrospectively assess the risk factors associated with intra-operative hypothermia in patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty from January 2016 to December 2017 at Aga Khan University and also understand it's impact on post-operative outcomes.

primary_outcome.description: Post-operative infection caused total knee arthroplasty
Body temperature after surgery when patient is in the recovery room.

study_pop.textblock: All adults greater than 18 years undergoing total knee arthroplasty from January 2016 to December 2017 at Aga Khan University were included in this study. A standardized proforma was used to collect data from online patient data system about patients' preoperative, intraoperative and postoperative details. Preoperative data included age, gender, and comorbid conditions. Intraoperative data was collected from the surgical and anaesthesia records and included surgical site, American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) Level, duration of surgery, preoperative body temperature, intraoperative body temperature and duration of surgery. Postoperative data included post-operative body temperature and whether the patient developed any surgical site infection.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- All adults greater than 18 years who underwent total knee arthroplasty.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Any patient below 18 years
